summary: A module creates a new module-type in the enclosing package.
details: A module is a component of a compilation-unit that usually corresponds to a source file.
Let T be the module-type of a module M:
T's fully-qualified name is obtained from the one and only module-directive in M.
T is a subtype of Module.
T is a subtype of AbstractModule.
T does not define any publically visible constructors.
This is because an instance of a module is a singleton object.
T defines a special method: instance() : T
This method is public and static.
This method always returns the singleton instance of the module.
T defines a special method: moduleInfo () : ModuleInfo
This method is public and final.
This method returns a singleton object that describes the module.
T defines a special method: moduleInvokeFunction (ArgumentStack, int) : Object
This method is public and final.
This method is a low-level method that is not intended for direct use by programmers.
This method is used to implement delegates.
For each function F in M, there is a #public# static method in T.
Each @Setup function in a module is executed when the module is loaded and initialized by the runtime system.
The new type has public-access.
static-checks: A module must contain a module-directive.
A module can only contain one module-directive.
No two types can share the same descriptor.
No two functions in the same module can share their name and parameter-list descriptor.
example-1: module Main in examples;%0A%0A@Start%0Adefun main (args : String[]) : void%0A{%0A    (F::println %22Hello World!%22);%0A}
